title: How to Plant Vinca Minor

steps.headline: Purchase vinca minor seeds from an online supplier.
steps.description: Although you might be able to find seeds at local gardening stores, supply typically isn't consistent. Your best bet is to check online suppliers. Seed packs cost around $5 for 25 seeds.

steps.headline: Fill jiffy pots with 2.36 inches (6.0 cm) of peat moss or seed starting mix.
steps.description: These pots should be 2 to 3.5 inches (5.1 to 8.9 cm) in diameter. Peat moss is a form of soil that is partially decomposed and highly water saturated. It's perfect for vinca minor, which thrives in warm, fresh, and humid soils. Local department and gardening stores sell bags of peat moss for anywhere between $10 and $40, depending on the size and brand. Most jiffy pots are made of peat moss and wood pulp, which are 100% biodegradable. You can find them at local gardening stores or online suppliers for about $1 for a 10-pack.

steps.headline: Place your jiffy pots into a metal container with water.
steps.description: Fill the container with 2–4 inches (5.1–10.2 cm) of water. Exposing them to prolonged water contact causes them to swell—once they are thoroughly moistened, you can place it into a standard pot.

steps.headline: Put your swollen peat into 2.36 inch (6.0 cm) deep plastic pots.
steps.description: Once the moss has swelled from water absorption, place it into a plastic pot immediately. Leaving your peat pots in water after they have swollen up can lead to fungal growth.

steps.headline: Spread your vinca minor seeds over the peat.
steps.description: Layer them over the soil and then cover them with approximately 0.25 inches (0.64 cm) or less of peat moss. Gently press down on the soil with your hands. Use a spray bottle to spray the top of the soil with water after layering it onto your seeds.

steps.headline: Wrap each pot in a Ziploc bag or cover it with plastic wrap.
steps.description: Open up a Ziploc bag and place each pot into it from the top opening. Pour a little bit of water into the pot using a small cup, seal the Ziploc bag, and then place it on a window sill. Ziploc bags trap moisture are help the seeds germinate. If you don't have any Ziploc bags handy, you can sow your seeds under a glass container. You should begin by lining the bottom of a cloche container with pebbles for drainage, placing the plant on top of them, and then covering the container with its lid. It should be placed in a bright spot that is away from direct sunlight to avoid generating too much heat.

steps.headline: Plant your vinca minor when temperatures are around 24 to 38 °C (75 to 100 °F).
steps.description: Hardiness zones 4-8 are the optimal regions for periwinkle growth. In terms of temperatures, plants hardy to zones 4-8 can withstand a minimum temperature of −30 to −37 °F (−34 to −38 °C) once they are established. Vinca minor thrives best in 24 to 38 °C (75 to 100 °F) daytime temperatures, while nighttime temperatures should be between 20 to 24 °C (68 to 75 °F). Although temperature is important, vinca minor is a hardy plant that can successfully thrive in a wide range of temperatures. Look at the worldwide U.S. plant hardiness zones here: http://www.plantsdb.gr/en/general-cultivation/hardiness-zones/274-hardiness-zones-map.

steps.headline: Choose planting locations at least 3 feet (0.91 m) from boundaries.
steps.description: Avoid planting vinca minor close to its boundaries—they are trailing and shallow-rooted, which can easily turn them into invasive plants. Focus on regions close to concrete paths and sidewalks to check its growth. But remember: sometimes it will even grow over these regions. Avoid planting vinca minor next to natural areas to prevent disruption of local habitat.

steps.headline: Select a planting location with 3 to 6 hours of daily sunlight.
steps.description: Also known as partial sunlight, this exposure can be continuous or intermittent. This term is interchangeable with the term partial shade. Too much sunlight leads to decreased vigor of your vinca minor plants.

steps.headline: Loosen the soil with 2 inches (5.1 cm) of organic matter.
steps.description: Use a small gardening shovel to dig about 3 to 6 inches (7.6 to 15.2 cm) into the soil. Add some organic matter, such as mulch and compost, into a 2 inch (5.1 cm) layer over the soil surface and till it in using an electric or hand tiller. About 5 to 15 percent organic matter in your soil is optimal. Compost will help loosen the soil, provide nutrients for your plant, and improve drainage. Vinca minor's small, trailing roots need plenty of space to grow quickly.

steps.headline: Prick your plants out of the small pots after 3 to 6 weeks.
steps.description: Pricking is the process of removing seedlings from their trays or pots following germination (usually when the first set of leaves emerges) and growing them in pots. Gently hold the seeds by their leaves and use a pencil or dibber to remove the plant from the compost. Rest the roots on the dibber or pencil, and try and save as much root as possible. Maintain a distance of 0.78 to 1.18 inches (2.0 to 3.0 cm) between each plant. Always lift each seedling one at a time, and never hold them by the roots or stem—this can damage the plant. A dibber is a pointed stick that creates holes in the ground.

steps.headline: Space your plants 6 to 8 inches (15 to 20 cm) apart.
steps.description: Vinca minor plants have trailing roots that pave the way for a spreading ground cover growth habitat. Giving them enough space is especially important if you're planting them specifically for ground coverage. In terms of height, each plant will grow to around 4 to 6 inches (10 to 15 cm) off the ground once mature. The average diameter of vinca minor plants is around 3 feet (0.91 m).

steps.headline: Water your plants until they are moist, but not soggy.
steps.description: Through the first season of growth, ensure that all plants are evenly watered—this promotes proper rooting. In terms of frequency, this depends on location. For sunny spots, daily watering is ideal. For the first season, deep, infrequent watering is preferable. Skip watering on wet, rainy days.

steps.headline: Prune vinca minor in the spring to prevent invasion.
steps.description: Use pruning shears to cut any damaged, dead, or dying leaves back to the node located right before the damaged region. Keep as many branches with closed buds as possible, as this will ensure your vinca minor can continue sprouting. Cutting back your vinca minor is not necessary, and should be reserved for situations where growth is becoming invasive. Cuttings left from pruning can be used for propagating more plants.

steps.headline: Combat rust and grey leaf spot disease using pesticides or selective removal.
steps.description: Although periwinkles are robust and thus very resistant to pests and diseases, they are vulnerable under certain circumstances. For example, rust (known for causing round, black-brown spots) can infest at locations that have high humidity and requires pesticide treatment. Grey leaf spot disease can be spotted by its brown patches, and at early stages it can be fought by removing affected parts of the plant. Remove rust with chemical agents or remove affected plants completely. Plant parts affected with grey spot should be removed immediately. Always make sure plants are spaced enough for adequate air circulation and your planting region is not too humid.

tyn_section: Organic matter (such as mulch or compost)
